messages.content: A crypto artist who absolutely loved it. There were lots of artists, a majority of artists, but also quite a few engineers, curators. There was Luc Jeudet too who came from NFT Factory. Then there was Operator, there was Sam Jansen, Sam Jay, So they're more performance artists, but who work heavily in NFTs. So actually, there was kind of this idea of... There was TerraZero too, Sacha Styles, Milos Manetas, etc.
There were quite a few people though.

Yeah, exactly. Listen, we were actually a bit too many. In total, in two weeks, I think we were about sixty, knowing that not everyone was there at the same time. But the idea was really to focus on, while the subject was the metaverse, actually we wanted to focus heavily on interdisciplinarity, and so to have artists who do a bit of everything from poets, musicians, dancers, and visual arts, to precisely explore this concept of the metaverse, in a way that's not only in the sense of the metaverse, purely digital, but really the metaverse which is kind of this intersection between the physical world, the virtual world, and which will create bridges between these different physical and virtual universes. It was very interdisciplinary. and it was quite cool because precisely, the idea of Glitch is that normally, maximum, you have 35 at the same time. So, you have 35 people who really come from different disciplines, but who are still very aligned in terms of values and trajectory, towards what society do we want to go. And actually, who live for two weeks under the roof of a very beautiful castle in Burgundy. And actually, there's not really a program, that is to say there's no structure, there are no talks, etc., that are pre-programmed. But it's only a program that is co-created by the participants. And the goal is really serenity, cross-pollination and collaborations that will be created as people meet.
Great. So, are there precisely some collaborations or interesting reflections that marked you, for example?

So, there are several projects that are emerging from all this, which is kind of the goal. There's a project that's quite fascinating, it's the cube. So, actually, during Glitch, there's a small group of artists who got together and who wanted to offer the metaverse to the physical world and so who created a cube, a cube of I think 3 meters by 3 meters, covered with canvases and with a series of 5 projectors that project onto the canvases of this cube. so that there were people inside who were walking around in the metaverse and it projected what they saw onto the canvas of the cube and you could enter the cube and you were in the metaverse and you could interact. There were people who embodied themselves in the metaverse and who allowed this kind of interaction with physical people and digital people. And so there, this project which apparently is becoming... It was a prototype, it was done a bit hastily, of course. But now, the cube which is becoming a real project, which will reproduce itself and so with NFT elements that will be integrated. Then, there's a very cool project too, which wasn't born there, but which grew there. It's the Aminals project. And the Aminals, actually, once again, it's another typology of blockchain-based life forms, but this time which is purely digital. And the Aminals, so they're little aminals, but they're aminals, which are creatures on the blockchain and which are NFTs, but which are NFTs that you can't own. Actually, the idea was, but what is a purely digital creature on the blockchain? And actually, we don't really want people to own the creatures and speculate on the value of the creatures. And so actually, we conceptualized this whole model where the aminals are NFTs that you don't own but that you can interact with and that can attach to you. And when you can feed them, so actually it's kind of a crypto black hole, you can feed them, you can play with them, etc. It always involves giving them crypto. So they accumulate lots of crypto. For example, if they're hungry and you feed them, they'll attach to you. If they feel lonely and you go play with them, they'll also attach. And when they attach to you, you can ask them to move in the metaverse, to move to coordinates that you desire, so they can follow you, or you can tell them to move X, Y, and then you have the possibility, when they're very very very attached to you, you have the possibility to genetically modify them, and so to inject new genes into these aminals, And then the aminals can reproduce with each other, and when they reproduce, they integrate the genes. And so if your gene has been reproduced, when a new aminal is generated, all the people who participated in creating the genes of a new aminal will actually receive a portion of all the crypto that the aminals have collected so far. And so the goal is to have aminals that are your friends. And so instead of... In your wallet, you can show not only the NFTs that you own because you bought them on the market, but you can also show the aminals that love you and so the aminals that are close to you. But actually, you have no exclusivity over these aminals, that is to say that if someone else goes to feed them or take care of them, suddenly, they'll start sharing their affection between several actors. And so, actually, it's a different model of showing, listen, I have this affection.
Your aminals are kind of liquidity chickens, aren't they?

No, not at all, but it's another model. Because actually, the only way you'll get money back from the aminals is that you contributed to their genetic evolution and they reproduced and your gene was selected. So it's a bit more complicated to get rich than through a liquidity pool, but also it's a liquidity pool that reproduces. And so actually if you found this gene which is an absolutely popular gene and actually all the aminals reproduce and everyone sees this little gene, Actually, there, you can make a lot, a lot of money, but on the other hand, it's very possible too that you spent several tens or hundreds of ETH feeding your aminals, but actually, you'll never receive anything.

The concept is both funny and super interesting. Indeed, they're Pokémon that you don't own. They're free-range Pokémon and so for you, it's the fox from The Little Prince, you have to know how to tame it.
That's it, you have to tame them.
Very good.

Even taming them, you can give them orders, you have more probability that they'll listen to you, but that's not what will give you money and the only way you get a little money back is because you innovated at the level of really their genetic code. in an original and interesting way, which will therefore lead to the reproduction of these young ones.
Okay. Who are the artists who worked on this?

Listen, it's a collaboration, so it was mainly me, Lewis Parker, Isaac Padka and Will Paper. It was kind of a four-way collaboration, but well, it was mainly a project. We discussed it all together at Glitch, everyone gave feedback, etc. And so there, we're going to implement it soon. So, it's super interesting. And then, another quite interesting project that came out was this kind of art protocol, where actually, what we want to do is... So there, we're going to organize a festival. Well, we're going to participate in a festival, notably at Château du Fé, next September. and there will be a whole Glitch chapter at the festival. And the idea is that actually, we want to create works that are protocolar, that is to say that actually, they feed on data from other works and they provide data for other works. That is to say that actually, there's this kind, we're creating this protocol, so a smart contract, that each work that wants to plug into the Glitch protocol will be able to integrate, whether it's a digital work or a physical work. For example, in the case of the plantoid, the plantoid that will collect data to create NFTs, it will also record this data on a smart contract that's part of the Glitch protocol. That means that suddenly, if you want to create another work, which can be a digital work or not, you're going to create an NFT, you can choose that the NFT will plug into the plantoid's data. And so, actually, the plantoid becomes the input for the generation of an NFT, or vice versa, the plantoid could decide that actually, it's going to listen to information from a performance that's done by other artists, who are also plugged into the Glitch protocol. And so, the NFTs that it will generate are informed by the data that comes out of another work. And the idea is to create this new concept of collective work, but collective work not because everyone works on the same work, but because actually it's kind of plug and play, it's composability, it's works that feed each other with data, and since most of these works are based on a form of generative art, the instantiation or manifestation of these works depends on the manifestation of another work that has plugged into the same protocol. And the idea is that precisely, it allows you to make glitches, since if I know that I have another work that relies on my data, on the data from my work to manifest itself, I can try to make it glitch. And so actually, since they're all connected, interconnected and dependent on each other, you can play on affecting another person's works, either in a standardized way, in an expected way, or in an unexpected way. And so, when you connect to the glitch protocol, it means you never know when your work will glitch, because someone will try to, not hack, but circumvent the data a bit to see what it gives in another work.
So in the end, the protocol is itself a kind of global collective work.
It's a rhizomatic work that integrates many works, well all the works that want to connect to the same, to the glitch rhizome.
Okay, okay. And so what is it a bit, it's a bit like a kind of API for artists who will be able to on screen.

Yeah, it's a form of API and factory, so it's really a smart contract that you plug into this protocol smart contract, you I left from Urizam, and so your output data can become the input data of any other work that wants to plug into you. And you, you can plug into all the output data that will become your input data for your work.
OK, very good. It's very clear. It's very fun. Then just from 3-4 works at the start, you can start creating something interesting.
Exactly.
Okay. So Rémi I think he's a bit too much in space there. Rémi?
Are you still there? I'm completely lost there. Actually the problem is that I let go at some point and I tried to run after but I never caught up with you.
That's good, thanks for bringing us back to earth.
Actually I had a question but it's so... It's so upstream of everything we've said. Well, never mind.
Go ahead, go ahead.
No, no, no.
Ah well there you go, Rem, go ahead, ask your question.
Go ahead!

So you see, Primavera, I have a problem, it's that every time I start talking about NFTs to people who don't know much about it, inevitably I get to a point where I talk about blockchain. And there, there's this famous question, but what is blockchain? And actually, I always have a lot of trouble explaining simply. And I wanted to know if, by chance, you had a way of giving a simple definition to the people you meet who ask you this question. Maybe an analogy or something...
Actually, I confess, I've reached a level where, actually, if there's a person who answers me not to the question, I run away.
That's not bad either. OK.
But you can tell them to... to read my "Que sais-je" [What do I know? - a French educational book series], Blockchain and cryptocurrency.
Which explains... And there you go, that's perfect.

In 100 pages, what is Blockchain? No, but actually, honestly, I think that today, it's still difficult for people not to have a vision, even a bit approximate, of what Blockchain is. Actually, it doesn't happen to me much that people ask me, but what is Blockchain? I think I don't hang out with those people, I only hang out with people who know a lot about Blockchain.

I confess that I try to dodge by saying, OK, I'm not going to explain to you what it is, but I'm going to explain to you what it's for. I try to dodge the question a bit like that. It's not always easy.

In reality, the definition is very simple. I think it's a register, a cadastre, a register, I don't know. It's a decentralized register or cadastre. that allows recording transactions chronologically and securely. And once the transactions are recorded, you can't erase them anymore.
That's about what I try to tell them.
I don't know if it helps much.
Exactly.

I had a friend who had an analogy. He called it the magic book, because it's a book in which you can write pages, but you can never erase them. And when you write a page in your book, all the people who have the same copy of the book, they'll see the new content. Actually, it's kind of a decentralized book, where all the people who have the copy of the same book, they can write according to certain rules, And once you've written, you never erase. But the fact that you wrote on your copy of the book, actually, all the copies, it's kind of... That appeals to me.
I like that, the magic book story.
I could explain to children, you know.
Not bad, that was super interesting. So, Benoît Couty who spoke earlier, from the museum, as you described, from Mocha, from French Mocha. Benoît, you were also, you also went to Glitch.

Yeah, I had that chance, thanks Primavera, it was incredible. I arrived at the end, the last three days, and I was blown away, you know. I arrived, and this castle, already, this place which is incredible, which is lost in the middle of nature, we're far, a bit far from everything, and you enter, and it's like you can imagine in castles, there are several lounges that connect, and so I enter this castle, I start entering the lounges, and I see... people discussing everywhere in small groups, computer equipment everywhere, computers, soldering irons, weird objects, screwdrivers, leaves hanging from the ceiling because they're drying. It was really an incredible atmosphere. I really loved it. I had a great time. I met lots of incredible artists. It opened my eyes to lots of things. Yeah, and then... And then there are incredible projects. I really liked the discussion we had Primavera about protocalism. It's something I was in contact with, somewhere that I saw, but that I hadn't elaborated like you did. and I found this discussion incredible. And then, to see these artists who...

It should be said that I leave Primavera on this concept, which is a kind of artistic practice which is to define a protocol, and actually, the art is not what comes out of the... it's not the production, it's the definition of the protocol that will then result in works that will be produced, but the artist creates the protocol. I don't know if that's well summarized.

Yes, actually the idea, I call it a new artistic movement, but actually it's very present notably in AI. That is to say that when you're an AI artist, what do you do? You're going to create a protocol and then you give the protocol to a model or to an AI and the AI will generate works based on this protocol. But actually, you are the artist of the protocol and so you are the artist of the result. And actually it applies easily, it's easily observed in the world of AI, but actually it applies perfectly also in any other domain. And so notably for example the plantoid, it's a protocol, that is to say that I created the plantoid protocol, when then there's another artist who will create a new sculpture because they were hired by a plantoid, they are actually creating a plantoid and so they are creating my work. And the idea of protocalism is precisely the goal, whereas with usual copyright, the reproduction of a work is a copyright violation that will encroach on the interests of the artist. In the case of protocalism, the reproduction of the work, actually, is production. That is to say that actually I need people to reproduce my work as a protocalist because they are producing new works, even if it's them who produce them. In reality, each of these productions and reproductions embodies the artist's protocol and so actually each work instantiated either by a machine, or by an AI, or by a human, will contribute to increasing the quantity of works that the protocalist artist has generated without them having to work. And so the idea is also to go into this new creative process where actually you invent The protocol, actually Sol LeWitt, I think is perhaps the most telling example of one of the very early protocalists, where precisely you give instructions and then people will create by following the instructions. But the creation, the artistic and creative work, It's a collaboration, so there's always the protocalist who invented, who created the protocol, who is therefore the artist of all the works that embody this protocol. And then, each person who will instantiate the protocol is also an artist, because they have the choice of how to instantiate. So there's also a form of artistic discretionary capacity. And so each work is a collective work between the person who created the work and the protocalist.

I really like this concept because actually it's something that exists and has always existed but that we've perhaps never formalized and I find it very interesting because it's very interesting to qualify the person who defines the protocol as an artist and maybe it also removes the weight of having to produce to valorize their protocol since the very fact of inventing a protocol becomes a work of art. and so there's less this pressure to say ok I invented a protocol now I have to produce things behind it to valorize my protocol because otherwise someone will quote unquote steal my idea and the fact of formalizing the thing by saying the protocalist is a full-fledged artist I find that's something very interesting. After that it raises questions of intellectual property rights and obviously Primavera is aware. But I find that in the approach, it's super interesting to formalize this thing, which actually has always existed. I think Primavera, you agree, there have always been artists who were protocalists, but who then produced themselves on their own protocol. But there, the fact of giving this quality to the person who invented this protocol, it brings something.

Okay. Actually, it touches indeed it touches many subjects, and I think that's what's interesting in what you do too, in this reflection that you have after Mavera, it's that finally this plantoid notably, actually at the base it was there a bit to materialize what a DAO was, and then by evolving it finally materializes a little bit towards what the artistic world could also evolve with this new form by materializing ultimately this new form of copyright. I see it once again as today, we spend our time already relying on, borrowing from others. And so, it's simply assuming it a bit more and putting it at the heart of the reflection, quite simply.

Exactly. And actually, it's showing that many of the things we consider negative for the artist can be extremely positive. depending on what typology of artist you are and depending on how you're going to formalize your work. I find the idea very interesting. Actually, the protocalist, it's great. You create your protocol and then, the whole world becomes your assistants. The agent works for you because people who find your protocol interesting and who decide to instantiate it in their own works, actually, they work for you and you don't need to hire assistants. You have people who, for their own pleasure and for their own benefits too, they think this protocol will contribute to their own work and so they create a work with your protocol. But actually, it means they also created a work of your protocol.

Yes, and then I think there are maybe certain artists, certain personalities who are more able to create protocols and less able to produce what comes out of the protocol. And somewhere, when we qualify the artist as a protocalist, we free them from this obligation to produce and we give them more opportunities to create protocols. So if you want, it's also something that... that can boost creation a bit in that direction.
Exactly.

Actually, it's interesting because we see that we're only at the beginning of this reflection. Once again, we'll have to follow this, learn. I don't know how you see the temporality in this, by the way, Primavera, because you, it's already been a few years that you've been playing, experimenting on it. Before it touches the art world in a fairly significant way, is there still a lot of time for you Primavera?

Listen, me, actually, for me, the protocalism movement already exists, it's just that it hasn't been named. And so, actually, I think there are many artists who are already protocalist artists, who don't know it because they don't know the name. So, for me, it's enough to... It's kind of my mission, there, it's to try to... to communicate this new concept of protocalism as an artistic movement so that all protocalist artists, actually, it resonates immediately. There was notably Fernando Haglich. He doesn't stop, he said, but it completely... I discovered being a protocalist and suddenly, all his work makes so much more sense. So actually, I think artists who are protocalists, the moment they hear the description, the explanation of this concept, they recognize themselves immediately. And it's just that they didn't know they were part of the same movement, because often, they're artists from very different disciplines, etc. And I find it super interesting to launch the idea of this movement in the air and then to allow artists with whom it resonates to group around this concept. And once the movement is not formed, because you don't form a movement, once the movement is recognized, suddenly it also allows inspiring other artists who perhaps are not yet in the protocalism approach, to experiment with these modalities.

Great. So, if you're a protocalist artist too, you can contact Primavera to join the family and claim yourself from this movement. It's extremely rich. Benoît, I think you had something else you wanted to talk about too, that had marked you, I think.

I can't find the activate microphone button anymore. I was impressed by UP250's cube, they did that in a few weeks. The POC was super nice and I really can't wait to see that. It's something that interests me a lot, notably at the factory, we're a physical place but we're thinking about the metaverse. And there we're really at the crossroads of both, with physical interactions, with people who on one side evolve in the metaverse, who have avatars, who are quote unquote visualizations of their avatars in a 3D world, and people who physically are immersed in screens and who can interact with these avatars. It's a bit of a meeting between the physical person and another person's avatar. It's a bit this dream, this theme that we often see with the Avatar film for example. It's a bit of a generic theme right now. And so there, there's the artistic version and the version that we can experiment with, so I was really impressed by this project. There you go, then beyond that, this Glitch residency, it's incredible for inspiring, it's incredible for meeting, it's incredible for discussing, there's a philosophical aspect that's very important. And so me, I can't wait to follow this and I hope Primavera will invite me for the next ones and it will be with great pleasure.
Obviously. And I hope that, John, you can come too next year.

Of course, I'll immediately mark that with a cross in my calendar. It sounds extremely exciting, indeed. And so, precisely, you're talking about next year. We'll have to leave soon maybe, but before that, just... So 2023, you told us, there already in September, you're going to do this... this festival, this expo, this fair? What's the exhibition?

It's an artistic festival which is a more generic festival. But I think Glitch will kind of co-opt part of the festival. And so all the artists who participated in Glitch in the past two years, we're going to invite them to create works for the festival, potentially works that will stay there, that will stay at the castle. and the idea is that all the works that will be in the festival must be part of the Glitch protocol, so they'll all be interconnected.
